title: 114_s3488
content: The "SuperPAC Elimination Act of 2017" eliminates certain contribution limitations. The purpose of this section is to allow unlimited direct contributions by citizens and lawful permanent residents of the United States to candidates in Federal elections. Amendments are made to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to eliminate certain contribution limitations. Amendments are made to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to allow unlimited direct contributions by citizens and lawful permanent residents of the United States to candidates in Federal elections. This includes changes to paragraph (2) and (3) of the Act, as well as conforming amendments to sections 315(a) and 315(c). Amendments are made to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to allow unlimited direct contributions by citizens and lawful permanent residents of the United States to candidates in Federal elections. This includes changes to various sections of the Act, such as striking specific references in subparagraphs and paragraphs. Amendments to the Federal Election Campaign Act now require a 24-hour notification for all direct contributions to candidates. Amendments to the Federal Election Campaign Act now mandate that if a candidate receives over $200 in contributions from a single contributor in a calendar year, their campaign committee must notify the appropriate authorities with details of the contribution. If a candidate receives additional contributions from a contributor after submitting a notification, the campaign committee must submit an additional notification. The committee is required to submit notifications for contributions over $200 from a single contributor in a calendar year. In the case of a notification for contributions exceeding $200 from a single contributor in a calendar year, the campaign committee must submit an additional notification within 24 hours of the contribution. The amendments made by this Act will apply to contributions for elections after the enactment date.
